hints_html:
Try using the point slope formula

\[\begin{aligned} y - y_1 = m(x - x_1)\end{aligned}\]

Where \(x_1, y_1\) are the coordinates of a point on the line.
hints_raw:
Try using the point slope formula 

:<math>y - y_1 = m(x - x_1)</math>

Where <math>x_1, y_1</math> are the coordinates of a point on the line.
question: 7 (a)
sols_html:
We know that our line passes through the point (1,1) and has slope m. Using the point-slope formula of line, we get

\[\begin{aligned} y - 1 = m(x - 1).\end{aligned}\]

Solving for y gives us \(y = mx -m + 1\)
sols_raw:
We know that our line passes through the point (1,1) and has slope ''m''.  Using the point-slope formula of line, we get
: <math>y - 1 = m(x - 1)</math>.  

Solving for y gives us <math>y = mx -m + 1</math>
